title: Did Elvis Presley write his own songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Writing songs is about the words, not the music. NOBODY has written original music since around the beginning of the 20th century…i.e.1900 or so. Its why songs that have huge success in the US are riddled with lawsuits. Most lawsuits are based on “respect of the songwriter”, even though acts like Michael Jackson have been sued. As far as Elvis, let's take his first hit as a possible example to shine some actual fact on this issue. Elvis was voted the most promising country music act of 1955. Through numerous industry channels, a person who knew a person had contacted one of the songwriters of Heartbreak Hotel. Durden, who knew Axton, then got together to pen the music, which is 8 bar blues. The story was inspired by a newspaper article. These two writers don't even agree on who wrote what when asked later in years. After the song was penned, Axton had gotten backstage at a Presley concert because of her connections and gave Elvis the demo tape which was piano and voice only. She told Elvis that if he recorded it as his first single at RCA he could have 1/3 songwriting “royalties”. She actually offered another person the same deal on royalties if he helped with polishing up the song. That person rejected the offer saying the song seemed to dark or morbid. Elvis actually performed it live early late 55 in concert before taking it into RCA studios and recording it in the first half of Jan.1956. After the record came out Presley had writers credit also, but more importantly, the songwriters did not initially realize that was their song when they had heard it because Presley had reworked aspects of the tempo, melody, etc…. RCA execs didn't even want to release it because of how strange the record was content-wise. Well, we know the history and this set the pace for Elvis’ approach to recording. Now, there are plenty of songs Elvis recorded that were simply him singing it because he liked it. There are Elvis songs that are his own style vocally, which made the song different. Besides scene-specific movie songs Elvis only recorded what he wanted to. But make no mistake, a Presley session was everyone could participate. Elvis was the bass player on “You're So Square, Baby I don't care” because it was an electric bass and Bill Black could not get the bass part the way Elvis wanted it having always been an upright player. How about another example “In the Ghetto”. The lyric “And his Mama Cried” was written by Elvis. Mac Davis penned the song but like most writers who Elvis recorded would later say that that small lyric made the song so much better than it was…. Larry Gatlin wrote “Help Me”….Elvis recorded it with such emotion, having recorded it on his knees as if humbling himself in prayer that Larry would later say Elvis gave him that song. Ever hear “Smokey Mountain Rain” by Ronnie Milsap? Milsap was the piano player on Elvis “Kentucky Rain”. During the session for the song, Elvis had told Milsap to “put a little more thunder” i.e. add thunderous sounding chords to the piano part in the song before the master take was recorded. Later on his own record Smokey, Milsap had gotten to the point where he wasn't satisfied with the presentation, he said it lacked something, that he had remembered the thunder that Elvis told him to do that he says, “Elvis was right, all Smokey needed was a little more thunder” Elvis was a songsmith. He created a style of rock and roll that nobody had done before. Levon Helm, “Elvis stood at the crossroads of white and black music. He erased the lines that separated the two and even threw in a little opera. Elvis came up with his own style of rock an roll”. Charlie Watts, ”We all heard those Elvis records. And of course, Elvis wasn't the blues he was just inspired by them” I could go on but no need to, I'm willing to admit that those people know more about music than I do. So you decide if “songwriting” is the same thing as making music.

Sadly, not only did EP not write his own songs, but his manager Colonel Tom Parker was made it impossible for the best Tin Pan Alley and Nashville songwriters to pitch new material to the King. The reason was simple. Human greed reigned supreme. Thomas Andrew "Colonel Tom" Parker was the Dutch-born American manager of Elvis Presley. He wasn’t a Colonel. He wasn’t even American, for he was born Andreas Cornelis van Cuijk in the Netherlands. And speaking of “going Dutch” Parker refused to pay top songwriters the going rate and “points” (as in 1% = 1 point) for their compositions. So the scuttlebutt was, “Let Elvis record one (and only one) of your songs, so that you have bragging writes, but don't get ripped off twice.” His manager was also the one behind all of the Elvis movies, and they were pretty bad (although it’s great to have Elvis “live on” on the silver screen). All the songs where written by movie studio writers who where…well, they were strictly B-movies! But EP was an amazing man. Through all of this crap, Elvis believed in “Taking Care of Business”. He was generous to a fault, delivered the goods, was often the first person on the set, and really cared. So even ridiculous songs meant to fill the space between EP saying such gems as, “Say, can’t you see the little lady doesn’t want to dance with you” which of course breaks out into a brawl, were delivered with sincerity and grace.

He did not write songs—But he was the Greatest Performer of All time! Elvis was and always will be The King of Rock and Roll NOTE——SEE BELOW According to the R.I.A.A., the governing body that certifies Gold, Platinum, and Multi-Platinum Record Sales, (Recording Industry Association of America) the Leading all time Artist in Record Sales is ELVIS PRESLEY. -Elvis is the leading sales artist for both Solo Artist or Group. -Elvis has sold over 2.5 Billion Records Worldwide. ( A Billion is 1 Thousand Million). -Elvis has been on the charts more times than any other artist or group. -Elvis has the most hits in the Top 100, the Top 40, The Top 10, and has had 32 Number 1 Records. -Elvis is the only artist inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, The Country Music Hall of Fame, The Gospel Music Hall of Fame, and The Rythm and Blues Hall of Fame. -Elvis was nominated for 41 Grammy Awards. John Lennon said: "Before Elvis there was nothing". Bruce Springsteen said: "There are pretenders and contenders... but their is only one King". Elton John said: "There is no one greater as an artist on this earth, Elvis was my inspiration... he is the Man. Period." Paul McCartney said: "Elvis has always been on Top... His records always made me feel good. I thought the Beatles had gold records, until I had a private tour of Graceland... the hall of Gold says it all... Elvis has the most Gold, Platinum, and Multi-Platinum sales of all of us.... amazing man... simply amazing". According to the R.I.A.A., with help from EMI, the Beatles place number 2 on the list of All Time Record Sellers with nearly 1.6 Billion Records sold worldwide. Hey Jude was their Biggest selling record followed by Yesterday.

Not only did Elvis not write his own material, but the melody from one of his most famous tunes, “Can’t Help Falling in Love”, credited to Hugo Peretti, Luigi Creatore and George David Weiss, was lifted from a song titled “Plaisir d’amour”, written in 1784 by French composer Jean-Paul-Égide Martini in 1746. The lyrics of “Plaisir d’amour” were taken from a poem written by Jean-Pierre Claris de Florian. According to Wikipedia, this is the English translation of the lyrics from "Plaisir d'amour": "The pleasure of love lasts only a moment, The grief of love lasts a lifetime. I gave up everything for ungrateful Sylvia, She is leaving me for another lover. The pleasure of love lasts only a moment, The grief of love lasts a lifetime. As long as this water will run gently Towards this brook which borders the meadow, I will love you", Sylvia told me repeatedly. The water still runs, but she has changed. The pleasure of love lasts only a moment, The grief of love lasts a lifetime." Quite a different sentiment from Elvis's version! However, to his publisher’s credit, unlike many famous artists from the ‘60s-’70s that essentially stole copyrighted music, songs like “Hound Dog” and others, that were covers of American blues hit records, were generally credited to the original writers in the liner notes of Elvis records.

No. Not in the sense that he sat down with a guitar and wrote an original composition which nobody had heard before. He was never a songwriter. He received songwriting credit on a few songs but they were all tracks that he was given co-writing credit on as part of a deal struck by his manager.  But Elvis wasn't just a mindless puppet in the studio. He put his stamp on every song he recorded to some extent. His early SUN singles for example weren't written by Elvis but they had his hand all over them. The arrangements for Blue Moon of Kentucky and That's All right were created by Elvis and Moore and Black (his band) in the studio. That's All Right isn't a radical departure from the original but Blue Moon of Kentucky is turned into a rock and roll number by Presley who changed the tempo and altered the arrangement entirely.

Yes and no. Elvis co-wrote 2 songs with his friends Charlie Hodge and Red West, "That's Someone You Never Forget" and "You'll Be Gone." Remember that in the 50's and in the early 60's a large number of singers/bands didn't need write their songs. Elvis was, as stated by other commenters, responsible for the arrangements of many of his songs; the first four that come to mind are "That's All Right," "Hound Dog," "Don't Be Cruel," and "Little Sister." Priscilla said that she didn't like the two songs that Elvis co-wrote and he never wrote again because he was devastated.

His manager, Colonel Tom Parker, saw to it that Elvis was forwarded a third of the royalty paid to songwriters in exchange for singing their songs. Of course that meant some songwriters stopped writing for him. I don't know if that means Elvis was automatically credited for the songs or if they just made the songwriters pay each time. He may be credited for a few. Bottom line: I don't think Elvis did much in songwriting. He was a performer. ADDED: And an arranger, as David Stewart points out in his reply. And by the way, there is nothing wrong with "just" being the singer or the arranger rather than a songwriter.

No the truth Elvis Presley wrote none of his songs. Different lyricists and composers wrote each of his songs. For example Kal Mann wrote the words to “Teddy Bear” Music was written by Bernie Lowe. Hound Dog was written by Leiber and Stollar. sp? Heck some songs such as Good Rockin’ Tonight and Milk Cow Blues were first written and recorded in the 40s and 30s respectively. “Its alright Mama “ was first recorded in the late 40s by Arthur “Bigboy” Crudup. Crudup wrote the words to the song. To repeat Presley wrote none of his songs.

Nope. Just stole copywrite credits. Probably all Colonel “The Crook" Parker's idea without Elvis' knowledge or participation. Elvis, who certainly has his faults, simply doesn't seem like that kind of person. Besides, for the most part, Elvis was generally satisfied with his career. (except in his later years) I also sincerely doubt EP even *cared* about that part of the business: if he did, he would have fired Ol Fatso Parker when it was revealed to him a few years after the fact.

Elvis’s greatest musical gift was his voice, by far. That’s not to say he didn’t pick up a guitar or sit down at the piano now and then. He did and he wasn’t bad. He was not a consummate song writer either. He’s credited with co-writing a small number of his songs, most notably “All Shook Up” and “Love Me Tender”. These were collaborative efforts to say the least. So to answer your question, not so much.

Elvis did not write most of his songs; however the song All Shook Up was co-written by Presley. “Since the huge success of Don’t Be Cruel, Elvis had been anxious to record another song from the pen of Otis Blackwell. Eventually, Blackwell came around with All Shook Up. Presley wasn’t completely satisfied with the song, and with Blackwell’s consent rewrote part of the lyrics.” -Elvis’ Golden Records, RCA Victor.

I think the answer is no the closest he came was Talk in your sleep which I believe was penned by his bodyguard. The song above was credited to Red West although,Elvis I believe owned a publication company with Tom Parker.
Sorry to say, Elvis never wrote a hit song…………or, it seems, even a song. I often wonder if he tried. He had so much other talent, it does not matter, eh? His is the King of Rock n’ Roll.
He wrote one song

No, Elvis wasn't a songwriter, he was a performer. He did get a one-third writing credit on some of his early hits, thanks to his con artist manager. But the people who wrote the songs were willing to pay that price to get him to record their stuff.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Mary Wilson and Avinash Hiremath

response.answer_text: None that I know of
